title: SB 1159
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. The Legislature aims to make cost, quality, and equity data available to promote innovative healthcare approaches in California. A data atlas will be used to assess healthcare needs, control costs, improve quality, and address health disparities. The legislation aims to improve healthcare quality, reduce disparities, increase transparency in costs, promote wellness programs, and educate consumers. It also focuses on efficient utilization of prescription drugs and technology while reducing wasteful healthcare practices. The California Health and Human Services Agency is tasked with researching the development of a cost, quality, and equity data atlas in accordance with the Civil Code. The California Health and Human Services Agency is researching the development of a cost, quality, and equity data atlas. Key data submitters include health care service plans, insurers, suppliers, providers, self-insured employers, and trust administrators for multiemployer self-insured plans. A comparative analysis of potential models used in other states will be conducted to determine additional information to include in the atlas. The data for the cost, quality, and equity data atlas will be sourced from health care service plans, insurers, and providers' claims data or encounter data. Pricing information for health care items and services will be gathered from allowed charges or proxy pricing information for meaningful comparisons of provider prices and treatment costs. The data for the cost, quality, and equity data atlas will include information on social determinants of health, clinical data from various healthcare entities, and governance structures involving healthcare stakeholders and experts. The agency will conduct research on funding approaches for the cost, quality, and equity data atlas while considering confidentiality laws. Consultation with healthcare stakeholders will be done, and results will be made public by March 1, 2017. The agency may use federal funds for the purpose of this section, and pursuant to Section 10231.5 of the Government Code, this subdivision shall become inoperative on January 1, 2021.
